posts.post_content:
Cross format staple. It's like an [Ancient Ziggurat](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ancient Ziggurat) that can be used to cast other spells such as [Dismember](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Dismember).  
  
The additional uncounterability effect is also extremely relevant against potential answers in every format.  
  
**Block**: ?? [Dissipate](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Dissipate)  
**Standard**: [Mana Leak](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mana Leak)  
**Extended**: [Spellstutter Sprite](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Spellstutter Sprite), [Cryptic Command](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Cryptic Command)  
**Modern**: [Spell Snare](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Spell Snare), [Remand](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Remand)  
**Legacy**: [Mental Misstep](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mental Misstep), [Counterbalance](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Counterbalance)  
**Vintage**: [Chalice of the Void](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Chalice of the Void) , [Force of Will](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Force of Will), [Mana Drain](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mana Drain)

posts.post_content: I'm a huge fan of legacy and this card can be used to really push aggro back into the game. Having force of wills and dazes constantly being used makes it tough to really get a offense going. This card allows you some defense while not being broken. Wastelands are a thing and this feels really balanced with the current meta. You really don't need to be using tribal either to use this effectively. It allows for a lot of options on the draw and protects a threat. Actually getting to stick a Dark Confidant feels nice once in a while.

posts.post_content:
For the record, this was designed primarily in an attempt to counterweight [Snapcaster Mage](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Snapcaster Mage)'s tendency to grant far more counterspells than usual. One gets the feeling it didn't quite succeed at keeping the scales from careening in any direction...(wonders if anyone ever considered just banning Snapcaster, as per [Stoneforge Mystic](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Stoneforge Mystic), but was shouted down by the singles market...and what it's going to take to get curly braces to actually appear properly in comments)  
  
Maybe this would have worked better: Only one tap ability for one colorless, and if spent on the target creature type, it becomes uncounterable (read: remove the mana-fixing element). A non-legendary sort of [Boseiju, Who Shelters All](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Boseiju, Who Shelters All)...except for the not-so-tiny detail that Boseiju also required life payment...

posts.post_content:
Here, I think, is a good way to look at the [Snapcaster Mage](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Snapcaster Mage) vs. Cavern of Souls "OP" argument.  
  
When played against any deck archetype other than Control decks, Cavern of Souls is a Tribal mana-fixer. A really good one, but nothing more. And the mana-fixing only works for creatures. If a deck has no countering spells, it's second ability is virtually meaningless to the opponent.  
  
However, [Snapcaster Mage](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Snapcaster Mage) can dominate against almost every deck archetype. It doesn't matter if the opponent is piloting Zombies, Delver, or really anything else, as Snapcaster retains his value completely. Plus, you are using spells twice, which means card advantage. Cavern of Souls cannot bring anything back from the grave....well except [Gravecrawler](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Gravecrawler), but that's semantics.  
  
So, if you look at the two in terms of opponent-deck-type ratio, I'd say [Snapcaster Mage](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Snapcaster Mage) is the far more broken card.
posts.html:
Here, I think, is a good way to look at the Snapcaster Mage vs. Cavern of Souls "OP" argument.

When played against any deck archetype other than Control decks, Cavern of Souls is a Tribal mana-fixer. A really good one, but nothing more. And the mana-fixing only works for creatures. If a deck has no countering spells, it's second ability is virtually meaningless to the opponent.

However, Snapcaster Mage can dominate against almost every deck archetype. It doesn't matter if the opponent is piloting Zombies, Delver, or really anything else, as Snapcaster retains his value completely. Plus, you are using spells twice, which means card advantage. Cavern of Souls cannot bring anything back from the grave....well except Gravecrawler, but that's semantics.

So, if you look at the two in terms of opponent-deck-type ratio, I'd say Snapcaster Mage is the far more broken card.

posts.post_content: I'm a huge fan of legacy and this card can be used to really push aggro back into the game. Having force of wills and dazes constantly being used makes it tough to really get a offense going. This card allows you some defense while not being broken. Wastelands are a thing and this feels really balanced with the current meta. You really don't need to be using tribal either to use this effectively. It allows for a lot of options on the draw and protects a threat. Actually getting to stick a Dark Confidant feels nice once in a while.

posts.post_content: This is what I use as my middle finger to counter spell decks. It makes my zombies and vampires not fall victim to the [Isochron Scepter](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Isochron Scepter), [Countersepell](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Countersepell) combo. But just in case I do run into that combo in my zombies I have two [Stifle](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Stifle)s but this card makes me not use them up against combos like that. Plus [Stifle](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Stifle) is the counter I like.
